awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Engaging Undergraduates in Interdisciplinary Evolutionary Science
awd_abstract_narration:
This REU Site award to the University of Iowa, located in Iowa City, IA, will support the training of 10 students for 10 weeks during the summers of 2019-2021. The focus of this REU is training in evolutionary science, with students working on research projects across several disciplines. Three academic departments will collaborate with the University of Iowa Museum of Natural History (UIMNH) to offer research projects that span a wide range of topics, including animal behavior, paleontology, and genome evolution. Students will work on evolution-themed projects in one of these specific areas, but will also work as a cohort to make broad connections among disciplines.  As part of the program, students will receive training in research best practices, participate in career workshops, create a digital exhibit for the UIMNH, and make formal research presentations based on their work. Housing, a meal allowance and stipend will be provided to all participants. Students from underrepresented minority groups and who have limited research opportunities at their home institution are especially encouraged to apply. Students will be selected based on previous academic performance, enthusiasm for conducting research, interest in specific faculty research projects, and potential for future success in a research-related career. 
 
It is anticipated that a total of 30 students, primarily from schools with limited research opportunities, will be trained in the program. Students will learn how research is conducted, and many will present the results of their work at scientific conferences. Students will also learn skills in science communication including digital museum exhibits to communicate the results of their research to the public.
 
A common web-based assessment tool used by all REU Site programs funded by the Division of Biological Infrastructure will be used to determine the effectiveness of the training program. Students will be tracked after the program in order to determine their career paths. Students will be asked to respond to an automatic email sent via the NSF reporting system. More information about the program is available by visiting https://biology.uiowa.edu/reu, or by contacting the PI (Dr. Andrew Forbes at andrew-forbes@uiowa.edu) or the co-PI (Dr. Maurine Neiman at maurine-neiman@uiowa.edu).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
During the summers of 2019, 2021, and 2022, the REU (Research Experiences for Undergraduates) Program in Interdisciplinary Evolutionary Sciences at the University of Iowa provided training to 30 undergraduate students. Most students belonged to groups underrepresented in the sciences or attended colleges that lacked the same opportunities for research experiences available at the University of Iowa. Eleven of these students are now enrolled in science graduate programs and eight more intend to apply to graduate school within the next two years.

Evolution is a fundamental principle of the life sciences, uniting many otherwise disparate fields. Exposure of undergraduate students to a wide breadth of projects under the umbrella of evolutionary science improves both their understanding of their specific project focus and their appreciation for interdisciplinary methods, ideas, and questions. The experience of living and interacting as a cohort of young scientists across the evolutionary sciences readies those students for graduate training across such seemingly disparate fields as ecology, cell biology, anthropology, and paleontology.

From 2019-2022, students in the program conducted hands-on research alongside faculty mentors from four University of Iowa departments. Projects covered a wide range of disciplines and approaches, including phylogenetics, taxonomy, molecular biology, animal behavior, cancer and disease evolution, community ecology, symbiosis, and biological anthropology. While individual students focused on their specific projects, interaction with their peers showed them the breadth of evolutionary science. Students also received training in responsible conduct of research, engaged in informational sessions about graduate school and other related career paths, and gained experience in presentation of scientific results at an all-campus undergraduate research festival. Participating faculty and graduate students in host labs also benefited from this award by completing a formal mentor training workshop that will have a lasting effect on their future work as mentors.

Students in this program made important scientific contributions through their research, including by coauthoring publications with their faculty mentors and presenting their results at regional, national, and international scientific meetings. Science communication was a key component of this REU experience, and to this end students in 2019 produced videos documenting their work, while the 2021 and 2022 cohorts made interactive poster exhibits. The 2021 and 2022 cohorts also helped facilitate a “BioBlitz” event wherein members of the public joined with professional scientists to document animal, fungal, and plant diversity in a restored prairie on the University of Iowa campus. Videos and interactive posters sharing student work with a general audience are available online (https://biology.uiowa.edu/reu).
